text:
For anybody tracking, I did the hubspot course today (and by did, I mean I answered all the quizzes and saved myself hours). If you use social media frequently then I don't think the Hubspot course above will help you learn anything.

At the end of the course, it suggests you move onto the Twitter strategy course. Here's the link for people after something specific: <https://app.hubspot.com/academy/2488278/tracks/65/intro>

text: Another POV here - I think it would also depend on where you want to go with your content career. Is your end goal more marketing-centric or business-centric? For me personally, I’ve always seen myself following a Marketing track. So, I selected a Marketing program that allowed me to focus on advanced marketing skills and also “minor” (for lack of a better word) in business management and take a few MBA classes to fill business gaps I have.

elements.text: Another POV here - I think it would also depend on where you want to go with your content career. Is your end goal more marketing-centric or business-centric? For me personally, I’ve always seen myself following a Marketing track. So, I selected a Marketing program that allowed me to focus on advanced marketing skills and also “minor” (for lack of a better word) in business management and take a few MBA classes to fill business gaps I have.

text:
Content is just reaching tipping point as a must-have job for more and more companies, unlike traditional marketing, which has been around for much longer. One part of the trend is an increasing number of companies with Chief Content Officers. This started picking up about five years ago, with public companies starting to consider such roles, for example. I know, because a headhunting agency reached out and asked for input as they were drafting a white paper or such for clients who were asking whether they should be considering such a move. And if you search on LinkedIn, you'll see some folks with such titles.

Given the trend, I made sure I was getting compensated at the equivalent level relative to those folks. I didn't fight for the title, which would have been superfluous in my case, because I was already serving on our exec team at NerdWallet and I reported to our CEO. I wouldn't have gained anything but a title, which to me, meh. (This varies with individuals, of course.)

Something to consider when shooting for titles — they often mean relatively little once you've achieved enough. At least some people think that — as long as your scope and comp are where you want them, that's most important, IMO.

And being say a VP means different things at different sized companies — it's really about what scope and what size of team(s) and resources you have oversight over that matter when it comes to roles.

FWIW, I've been recruited for C-level and VP of marketing roles. There's no consistency in what that means. Personally, though, I'm not interested in becoming head of marketing, whatever the title, because I wanna focus on content. That might have been different had this not been my second career.

With the cost and time of MBAs, it's worth consider the opportunity cost you'd pay. If you talk to some people with master’s they didn't get enough ROI. Of course, everyone is different.

Funny thing: I've actually mentored MBAs, including several from Harvard. I worked with many of them at NerdWallet, because we hired many BizOps people from Bain and such years ago. I ended up with three MBAs assigned to partner with my function in BizOps roles at one point, plus several MBAs whom I'd hired as editors. Among the latter, there was no difference in work performance compared with peers without MBAs and I didn't pay them anything more — businesses with common sense should pay for results, not credentials, unless the credential accrues to the bottom line directly or indirectly, IMO (because if you have the skills and they show up in your work, why does it matter how you learned them?).

I'm still close to the three Harvard MBAs I've mentored. But I've worked with and overlapped with so many people with educational pedigrees and such that I realized that the talented ones would've succeeded no matter what; the degree wasn't the differentiator.

I've also worked with a number of people with great resumes or credentials who were turkeys. Like I've been asked for guidance from MBAs who clearly learned little about business, because their questions were so basic I couldn't believe they were asking. LOL.

Worth mentioning, given your age: The trend among even major companies is to increasingly move away from requiring degrees. Instead, the secular trend will be more lifelong learning of various sorts, like online classes and programs. How that will affect top jobs at various types of companies is yet to unfold.

text:
Great question <@U02V08HJB8D>! I think a lot of us in this field toy with this decision. I know I have. For me, it's never been an issue. I worked in higher ed comms for a few years and that's the only time it has ever come up (they tend to like degrees in academia).

But I'll agree with <@U02VBUQR0E7>. It hasn't been an issue at all in recent hiring processes or chats with recruiters. The smart companies (the ones you want to work for!) are de-emphasizing higher education in lieu of experience.

Now, if you WANT to learn more about the business-end of markcomm or want to aim for a CMO title, it might be useful. What roles do you want in the next few years? What experience do you need? Think about where your resume is lighter and either take on responsibilities that address it or supplement with education. I would try to work for a company that would pay for some of it though. Degrees aren't cheap!

text: *What does an “editorial lead” or “editor in chief” do vs. an editor?* Looking for real job descriptions, if possible.

elements.text: What does an “editorial lead” or “editor in chief” do vs. an editor?
Looking for real job descriptions, if possible.

text:
I just started a new role as the one-and-only content editor for a hypergrowth startup. The content team is currently 4 people but we plan to expand to 10-20 within a year (including writers, editors, and SEO specialists).

My boss (head of content) often says she wants me to morph into and “editor in chief” or “editorial lead” role without many more details. I imagine it’s less editing, more coaching a team of editors and writers, creating editorial guidelines, and creating briefs. But it’s all very hazy.

Do any of you have these mid-management editorial job titles? Managing editor, editorial lead, editor in chief — whatever’s between “editor” and “head/director of content.” I’d love real-life examples of duties and responsibilities, if possible, so I can steer the conversation.

elements.text:

Do any of you have these mid-management editorial job titles? Managing editor, editorial lead, editor in chief — whatever’s between “editor” and “head/director of content.” I’d love real-life examples of duties and responsibilities, if possible, so I can steer the conversation.

text: What do you think is the next promotion in line from a Senior Marketing Coordinator?  This person would essentially be the right-hand-person to the VP of Marketing, mentoring two marketing coordinators focused on digital (ads, PPC) and content (social media, blogs)

text: <@UPM3A8LTS> I just hired for this role (Content Editorial Manager) at my company. <https://www.builtinboston.com/job/content/content-editorial-manager/71105|Here's the job description> so you can get a sense of the responsibilities of an editorial lead. Essentially, building the systems that create smooth editorial workflows, reducing friction in the editing process, and being the "captain" of our editorial calendar. Ensuring that we're shipping high-quality content at a regular cadence.

attachments.fallback: Content Editorial Manager - Panorama Education | Built In Boston
attachments.text: Panorama Education is hiring for a Content Editorial Manager in Boston. Find more details about the job and how to apply at Built In Boston.
attachments.title: Content Editorial Manager - Panorama Education | Built In Boston

elements.text: I just hired for this role (Content Editorial Manager) at my company.
Here's the job description

so you can get a sense of the responsibilities of an editorial lead. Essentially, building the systems that create smooth editorial workflows, reducing friction in the editing process, and being the "captain" of our editorial calendar. Ensuring that we're shipping high-quality content at a regular cadence.

text:
There's no hard and fast definition of any of those roles — various companies and news outlets use the titles differently. And it often depends on the size of the operation.

I say this after having spent decades in daily news in newsrooms of varying sizes and then being exposed to many content roles. Like I just did a salary survey and, out of dozens of jobs, titles often varied for similar duties. And the smaller an org, the more they were jacks of many trades vs. specialists.

text: I have an executive editor title at my current company and have been working with an editor in chief and a managing editor, as well as editors. We divvy up stuff organically; we don't consult some standard definition of our roles.

elements.text: I have an executive editor title at my current company and have been working with an editor in chief and a managing editor, as well as editors. We divvy up stuff organically; we don't consult some standard definition of our roles.

text:
Even with exec titles, that can vary with the org and company size. Like I've seen VP and C-level titles at tiny companies that were clearly overinflated, versus legit exec roles with a meaningful set of responsibilities at larger companies.

At various companies, real execs aren't doing much hands-on work. They tend to handle strategy, decide direction and priorities at a high level, shape culture and such.

text: I suggest you discuss with your boss exactly what she means. And even if she describes with specificity, that can evolve as a company grows. Like if you're at a fast-growing startup, there's no way your job will stay the same even if you keep the same title.
